questions.text: What does npm stand for?

answers.description: This option is incorrect as npm stands for Node Package Manager, not Network Programming Module.
This option is incorrect as npm stands for Node Package Manager, not Node Preprocessing Machine.
npm is a package manager for JavaScript, allowing users to install and manage packages (libraries, tools, etc.) that they need for their projects.
This option is incorrect as npm stands for Node Package Manager, not Network Packet Manager.

questions.text: Why do developers use npm?

answers.description: npm is not used to create programming languages.

answers.text: To manage and install JavaScript packages
answers.description: npm provides a centralized repository where developers can publish and share their code, as well as tools to manage and install these packages easily.

answers.text: To write backend code for databases
answers.description: npm is not primarily used for writing backend code for databases.
Designing website layouts is typically done with HTML, CSS, and design tools, not npm.

questions.text: Which command in npm is used to search for a package?

answers.description: npm find is not the standard command for searching packages.
npm query is not the standard command for searching packages.
Developers can search for packages using the npm search command followed by the package name or keyword.
npm look is not the standard command for searching packages.

questions.text: What file contains the list of packages and their versions for a Node.js project?

answers.description: package.js is not the standard file for listing packages in a Node.js project.
node_modules.js is not the standard file for listing packages in a Node.js project.
modules.json is not the standard file for listing packages in a Node.js project.
The package.json file is crucial for any Node.js project. It lists all the dependencies and their specific versions, among other metadata about the project.

questions.text: How can you install a package globally using npm?

answers.description: npm local-install is not the correct command for installing a package globally.
npm install-global is not the correct command for installing a package globally.
Installing a package globally means it will be available for all projects on that system. This is achieved using the npm install <package-name> --g or -g flag.
npm add is not the correct command for installing a package globally.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the `node_modules` directory in a Node.js project?

answers.text: To store the source code of the project
answers.description: The source code is usually in other directories and files of the project, not in `node_modules`.

answers.text: To save all global npm packages
answers.description: Global npm packages are not stored in the `node_modules` directory of a specific project.

answers.text: To hold the installed project-specific npm packages
answers.description: Whenever you install a package using npm, it's stored in the `node_modules` directory of that project.

answers.text: To keep backup copies of old packages
answers.description: The `node_modules` directory holds the currently installed versions, not backups.

questions.text: How can you update all packages in a Node.js project to their latest versions?

answers.description: npm renew-all is not the correct command for updating packages.
The `npm update` command updates all listed packages in `package.json` to their latest versions, according to the version rules defined in the file.
npm upgrade-all is not the standard command for updating packages.
npm latest is not the standard command for updating packages.

questions.text: Which npm command allows you to view the installed version of a package in your project?

answers.description: The `npm version` command is used to bump the version of your project, not to check package versions.
npm show <package-name> version is not the standard command for checking package versions.
The `npm list` command displays the dependency tree of your project, and when used with a package name, it shows the installed version of that package.
npm inspect <package-name> is not the standard command for checking package versions.

questions.text: When installing a package, which flag will save it as a development dependency?

answers.description: The --global flag installs a package globally, not as a development dependency.
The --dev-only flag is not a standard npm flag for saving packages as development dependencies.
The --save-dev flag ensures that the package is listed under devDependencies in package.json, indicating it's only needed for development.
The --dev-dependency flag is not a standard npm flag for saving packages as development dependencies.

questions.text: Which file should be included in a `.gitignore` when working with Node.js projects to avoid uploading unnecessary files to a repository?

answers.description: The `package.json` file is crucial for defining project dependencies and should be included in version control.
.npmrc contains npm configuration but is not as bulky as the `node_modules` directory.
The `node_modules` directory contains all the installed packages, which can be bulky. It's unnecessary to include in version control since the `package.json` file already lists the required packages.
.env files should also be ignored (they contain sensitive environment variables), but the main file related to npm is `node_modules`.

questions.text: How can you install a specific version of a package using npm?

answers.description: The == is not the correct syntax for specifying versions in npm.
The syntax for installing a specific version of a package is to use the @ symbol followed by the version number.
npm install-version is not a standard npm command.
npm get is not the correct command for installing specific package versions.

questions.text: Which command can help you identify outdated packages in your Node.js project?

answers.description: npm check is not the correct command for checking outdated packages.
npm verify is not the standard command for checking outdated packages.
The npm outdated command lists all packages that have newer versions available than the ones currently installed in your project.
npm validate is not the standard command for checking outdated packages.

questions.text: If you want to uninstall a package from your Node.js project, which npm command should you use?

answers.description: npm delete is not the correct command for uninstalling packages.
npm remove is not the correct command for uninstalling packages.
npm discard is not the correct command for uninstalling packages.
The npm uninstall command is used to remove a package from a Node.js project.

questions.text: Which file contains user-specific configurations for npm?

answers.description: npm-config.json is not the standard configuration file for npm.
The .npmrc file contains user-specific configurations for npm, which can be located at the user's home directory or at the root of a project.
npm-user.json is not the standard configuration file for npm.
.npmconfig is not the standard configuration file for npm.

questions.text: What does the `npm init` command do?

answers.description: Git operations are not directly related to npm commands.
Starting processes is not the purpose of this command.

answers.text: Installs all packages listed in package.json
answers.description: Installing packages is done using the `npm install` command.

answers.text: Creates a new package.json file in the project
answers.description: The `npm init` command starts a prompt to create a new `package.json` file, which will contain project metadata and dependencies.

questions.text: When you install a package without the `-g` flag, where is it installed?

answers.description: The package is installed locally in the project's node_modules directory, not globally.
The package is installed locally in the project's node_modules directory, not in the system directory.
Packages installed without the -g flag are installed locally in the project's node_modules directory.

answers.text: It's not installed; it's only cached
answers.description: The package is indeed installed locally.

questions.text: Why might a developer choose to save a package as a devDependency instead of a regular dependency?

answers.text: Because devDependencies are faster to install
answers.description: The installation speed is not a factor in this distinction.

answers.text: Because devDependencies are only needed during development and not in production
answers.description: devDependencies are packages required during development, not in production.

answers.text: Because devDependencies are free while regular dependencies are not
answers.description: The cost is not a factor in this distinction.

answers.text: There's no difference; it's just a naming convention
answers.description: There is a functional difference in how these dependencies are used.

questions.text: What happens if you run `npm install` without any package name?

answers.description: Running npm install without a package name will not prompt an error.

answers.text: npm will install the latest version of Node.js
answers.description: npm install does not install Node.js itself.

answers.text: npm will install all the packages listed in package.json
answers.description: Running npm install without specifying a package name installs all the dependencies listed in package.json.
Running npm install without specifying a package name does not uninstall packages.

questions.text: Which npm command can be used to display a tree of all installed packages and their dependencies?

answers.description: npm tree is not the standard command for displaying the package dependency tree.
npm show-deps is not a standard npm command for displaying package dependencies.
The npm list command displays a tree-like structure of all installed packages and their dependencies.
npm display is not the standard command for displaying package dependencies.

questions.text: In what scenario would you use the `npm audit` command?

answers.text: When you want to check the npm version
answers.description: The npm audit command is not used to check the npm version.

answers.text: When you want to view the download statistics of a package
answers.description: npm audit does not provide download statistics of a package.

answers.text: When you want to check for vulnerabilities in your project's dependencies
answers.description: npm audit reviews the project's dependency tree for known vulnerabilities.

answers.text: When you want to publish a package to the npm registry
answers.description: Publishing a package is a different process and is not performed with npm audit.
